title: Taking azithromycin with other medicines and herbal supplements
description: NHS medicines information on possible interactions with azithromycin and other medicines, herbal remedies and supplements.
cleaned_text: Cautions with other medicines There are some medicines that do not mix well with azithromycin. Tell your doctor if you're taking any of these medicines before you start azithromycin: [antacids](/conditions/antacids/)for indigestion - ergotamine or dihydroergotamine - for migraine to help prevent blood clots - ciclosporin or tacrolimus - medicines to stop your immune system overreacting [colchicine](/medicines/colchicine/), a medicine used for gout and some other inflammatory conditions [digoxin](/medicines/digoxin/)for some heart problems - rifabutin, an antibiotic - nelfinavir, a medicine for HIV - a [statin](/conditions/statins/)medicine to lower your cholesterol, such as [simvastatin](/medicines/simvastatin/)or [atorvastatin](/medicines/atorvastatin/) Azithromycin can affect your heartbeat, so it's best not to take it with other medicines that have the same side effect. Tell your doctor if you're taking medicines that can affect your heartbeat, including: - any medicines for an irregular heartbeat ( [arrhythmia](/conditions/arrhythmia/)), such as amiodarone or [sotalol](/medicines/sotalol/) - antidepressants such as [citalopram](/medicines/citalopram/) - antipsychotics used to treat mental health conditions - some anti-sickness medicines, such as dimperidone - some antibiotics, such as moxifloxacin Check the leaflets that come with your medicines and talk to a pharmacist or your doctor if you are worried. Mixing azithromycin with herbal remedies and supplements There's not enough information to say that complementary medicines and [herbal remedies](/conditions/herbal-medicines/) are safe to take with azithromycin. They're not tested in the same way as pharmacy and prescription medicines. They're generally not tested for the effect they have on other medicines. Important: Medicine safety Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking any other medicines, including herbal remedies, vitamins or supplements.
